accordion.residueIntro: In the two to three days leading up to the colonoscopy, it's important to start adjusting your diet to help bowel cleansing. A low-residue diet is recommended, focusing on simple, cooked, easy-to-digest foods.
accordion.liquidIntro: On the day before the exam, the diet should be based on clear liquids to maintain hydration and support bowel cleansing.
accordion.residueShoppingNote: Keep the same list, but prioritize low-residue items.
accordion.liquidShoppingNote: Keep the list, but focus on clear liquids.

residueForbidden.title: Fruits
residueForbidden.detail: Raw fruits with peel and seeds

residueAllowed.title: Lean meats
residueAllowed.detail: Turkey breast, chicken breast, veal, or beef (boiled or grilled)

residueAllowed.title: Lean fish
residueAllowed.detail: Hake, mackerel, seabass, sole, or cod (boiled or grilled)

residueAllowed.title: White bread
residueAllowed.detail: Wheat bread, sliced white bread (no seeds), bread roll

accordion.dulcolaxReminder: Dulcolax at 48h and 24h before the exam (4 tablets total).
accordion.plenvuText: Prepare the solution according to the package instructions. Sip each dose slowly and alternate with clear liquids to stay hydrated. Always follow your doctor's prescription.
examChecklist: Insurance card or national health system card
Recent blood tests (within 6 months) including CBC, platelets, INR, and aPTT

faqs.question: Can I take my usual medication?
faqs.answer: Follow your doctor's instructions. Some medications may require adjustment.

faqs.question: Can I drink water on the exam day?
faqs.answer: It depends on the indicated time. Always respect the fasting period given.

faqs.question: What if I cannot finish the solution?
faqs.answer: Contact the hospital to receive specific guidance.

faqs.question: How do I know the prep was effective?
faqs.answer: Bowel movements should become clear/yellowish. If unsure, contact the team.
